DIV1.P: FROM Le Philosophe Mariè of M. N. Destouches.
AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, HAYMARKET, AND THE NEW THEATRE, PHILADELPHIA.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A library at SIR JOHN CLASSICK's.
DIV3.STAGE: SIR JOHN discovered at a table, musing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A scholar, a philosopher, to change his peaceful hours, his nights of study, and his days of fame!— And for what?—A wife!—A wife without a fortune too!—Where was my wisdom?—But young and handsome!—Where was my philosophy?—Where my pride, to do an act at which I blush?— [After sighing heavily, and shewing evident signs of uneasiness, he takes a book and begins to read—Dorimant enters un∣perceived by sir John, and seats himself at the table.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Laying down the book.] Ah! Dorimant, my friend, it is you I have to blame—You were the cause of my marriage—you painted wedlock with an eloquence that deluded me—Pictured my wife as soft, complying—

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: And is not she?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Starting.] You there!—Why do you steal upon me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Steal upon you!—Were you not talking to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Then you were guilty of very ungentel∣manly-like behaviour, to abuse me when you did not know I was present to defend myself. And suppose I advised you to marry; did not you ask my advice?— Were you not charmed when I gave my advice?—Be∣sides, is it possible you can repent?—With what on earth have you to reproach your wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Her indiscretion—which keeps me in perpetual torture.—She knows how much I feel on the occasion, and how earnestly I have entreated our mar∣riage might be kept secret; and yet it is her first pleasure the world should know she has a husband—and that I am the unfortunate man.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I can easily imagine your desire has not been strictly complied with—but you could not, surely, think to be married half your life without having it sometime or other known in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A secret alliance, formed near two years ago, without my father's consent or knowledge, would expose me to his just resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: His resentment will be easily overcome —for his obligations to you are so great—his affection for you so tender—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That I fear his sorrow, much more than his anger.—But there is another reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: That, indeed, has some weight; for you mean your uncle, the old rich contractor, whose obsti∣nacy and inhumanity, if he knew you had married a lady with a fortune unequal to that he means to give you, might cause him never perhaps to give you a shilling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And, beside these, I have another reason yet; one, which (to my own feelings) is of more consequence than any.—You know I have always made a jest of matrimony, laughed at, and ridiculed all husbands; I am therefore now ashamed, and blush at the title—There is something in marriage that takes from the dignity—

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P:
Will it take from the dignity of knight∣hood, which you have gained by your learned disserta∣tions?
No; nor can there be any reason but your uncle's displeasure why it should be any longer con∣cealed. Certainly you must pay some attention to that; and it ought to be a weighty consideration with your lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So it is, I dare say—but the pleasure of telling a secret weighs heavier far.—After all, she is not the only one who takes pleasure in propagating the news—her sister, to whom you design yourself the happy husband, has whispered the secret to most of her acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I am vext at such indiscretion, and will go to both ladies instantly with my complaint— [Going, returns.] And now do you apply yourself to study— and employ all your knowledge to obtain that degree of patience requisite to your state.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And do you furnish yourself with ample store against you marry my sister-in-law; for, by Hea∣ven, you will want it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I know Emily well—know all her faults —But love them all—even that pride which disdains me I approve; for while my unfortunate quarrel con∣ceals from her my real name and family, she is right in treating me so lightly.—Yet that she loves me, I am convinced; and, the moment my antagonist is pro∣nounced out of danger, I will silence every scruple, by revealing to her, that, instead of poor Dorimant, who has no other friend upon earth but you, I have a for∣tune and family as much above hers, as she now believes hers is above mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! I long to see you a husband—How mischievous does ill luck make a man! I have not one acquaintance at this moment that I do not wish to see married!
SP.STAGE: [He sits down and begins to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: [Looking at sir John.] Always reading! And never thinking of his wife day nor night. [Aside.] —Sir, sir, her ladyship desired me to come—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: "Her ladyship"—Do speak a little louder—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Her ladyship. Lady Classick.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Starting up.] Silence!—I thought, mrs. Lucy, I had a hundred times forbidden you to make use of that name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, sir—but when one forgets, I can't see what harm it can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You know you were amongst the few who were entrusted with the secret of our marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I have kept it a secret these two years! —Two years is a long time to hold one's tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But do you know what I may forfeit by your indiscretion—the wealth of which the displeasure of my uncle may deprive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I thought philosophers despised all such dirty dross as gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But, mrs. Lucy, although I may be of that opinion, perhaps my children may not, and I may one day be reproached for neglecting their fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: But, sir, your children are yet to come, and a philosopher's talent is to reform the world, but very seldom to people it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Entrusting you with a secret, mrs. Lucy, has given you a freedom that may very soon lose you your place.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Oh, sir! I am sure you know better than to turn a servant away, whom you have been obliged to trust with a secret.—There are many better ways to keep a servant silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And this I suppose is one?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, sir—and now I'll be silent for a month —and if you repeat this, at the end of that month, I'll be silent for the next—and so on. But, sir, I had al∣most forgot my errand—her ladyship—no—my mistress —not her ladyship—not your wife—but my mistress— sent me to ask if you will permit her to wait upon you here—as she has something particular to speak to you about.—Oh! she is here, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Have I not desired you a thousand times, madam, not to follow me here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And I have as many times obeyed you—but at present I want to speak to you on a subject of so much importance, to us both, that I have ventured to disobey your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: "Commands!"—You talk to me as if I were your tyrant.—I have but one command—Keep our marriage secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To keep it an entire secret is impossible; our living so long together, in the same house, though on a pretended visit to the mistress of it, is enough to create suspicion—The world has curiosity, and penetration.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And has no longer any doubt but we are man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Indeed!—Do they really think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes—and I fear, say so too.—Why these expressions of joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To have you for a husband is a happiness so flattering—a felicity of which I feel myself so proud— that to have it known, would give me infinite delight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: In contradiction to my will?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: —Perhaps the desire is wrong—but if it be my fault (I must own) it would constitute my greatest happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A woman's eloquence is irresistible. [A∣side.] But did not you promise me that your sister and your woman should be the only persons to whom you would confide this secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And you should accuse my sister, not me—It is she who has forfeited her word, not I.—I have kept mine but too well. Yet though by the concealment my reputation may be wounded, I submit without com∣plaint—But, if I make this sacrifice to you, suffer me to demand a small one in return.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: That lord Lovemore, either by you or by me, may be made acquainted with our marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: The very person of all the world I would most conceal it from; for to him more frequently than to any other person, have I declared my sentiments of the marriage state; and in what a despicable light, to him, must my inconsistency appear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: No—notwithstanding you are married, nei∣ther his lordship, nor any other person, most intimately acquainted with your former sentiments, can accuse you of inconsistency.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Did I not rail at marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Do you not now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But had I not an utter aversion to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And have you not now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But why should you be uneasy at that? I love you—and should like you better, if you were any thing but my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And being my husband, I love you far better than if you were any thing on earth beside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I will not have our marriage declared to any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yes! to lord Lovemore—you must consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: From what motive?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Excuse me—but be assured it is indispensible; and why have you such a particular apprehension of him; for although this lord is a fine gentleman, and in high esteem with the gay world, yet I have fre∣quently heard you speak but slightly of his understand∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Therefore I fear him—you know I always fear a fool—It is the fool, who laughs at the faults of wise men, because they are so unlike his own. 'Tis the fool who traduces their character—'Tis the fool who stops at no means to accomplish his evil wishes. —Fools dress to seduce women; lisp, chat, flutter, and even lie to win them.—'Tis fools, with whom men of sense cannot submit to quarrel, but must fall, like a poor female, by their slander.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P:
Why then this fool, in one respect, has shewn himself like you; for he never pays a visit to this house, that he does not immediately come to my apartments to
make the same declarations of love, and the same offer of his hand and heart, you once did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Starting.] To you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To me.—I once thought to keep it a secret. —But—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But that was impossible?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Yes—for the increasing ardour of his ad∣dresses makes it impossible to submit to the painful situ∣ation any longer—and surely there is no method so ef∣fectually and so delicately to put an end to his pursuit, as to declare I am your wife. [Sir John starts.] At present I will not urge you for a decisive answer—but leave you to reflect upon it.
SP.STAGE: [Bows, with a tender humility, and retires.]

DIV3.STAGE: [He sits down to write as before, then starts from his seat and throws the book down in a passion.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No—all my study is at an end for this day—my mind wholly dissipated with domestic con∣cerns—It is impossible for a married man to be a philo∣sopher—and yet it is a state that requires more philoso∣phy than any other.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Another apartment of SIR JOHN's.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Has lord Lovemore called this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Do you think he likes me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: No, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: But, I am determined to make him—and you know I will, if I say I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And if you should, what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Then I shall have the pleasure to tell him I despise him, and that his title, birth, and fortune could not recompense me for a man who had previously offered himself, and been refused by my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I cannot help thinking he loves her still.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
As much as a beau, who loves nothing so
well as himself, can love; and therefore it has long been my design to whisper to him, she is married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Do you suppose he will love her the less for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: His love being but a mere compound of vanity and gallantry, I should suppose not—but at least the news will mortify his pride—And why should not other people meet with mortifications, as well as I, Lucy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I am sure, madam, it is not your fault if they do not—for you are ever doing all you can to tease every body you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: If I could please them I should be equally content—but as in that my endeavours are mostly re∣jected, the only alternative I have to preserve me from idleness is to be mischievous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Nay, madam, do not say you please no one; consider mr. Dorimant.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And him I have no desire to please; for it is to my disadvantage we should be charmed with each other.—This is the hour he generally calls—Now, Lucy, do something to put me out of humour, that I may break with him at once—Come, talk on some subject to vex me—speak of my sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Ay, my mistress—the philosopher seems to have lost all his affection for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Pshaw! you know this pleases me—for it in some degree extinguishes that surprize I feel, while I cannot discover by what art she gained possession of a man of sense, of renown, in short, of such a man as sir John.—If he were my husband—as you know I wished him to be—I should have expected him to love me—but to have a tenderness for my sister!— [Angrily.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I still believe he has, in his heart, a most affectionate one.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Do you see Dorimant coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That you try to provoke me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes—as I live—here he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
I thank you then—for you have left me in
excellent humour.
SP.STAGE: [Exit Lucy.—Emily sits down, and appears meditating.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter DORIMANT, who looks at her some time, while she pretends not to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: You wish to be alone, I perceive. [He waits for an answer, then goes on.] But although I may disturb you, I cannot forbear—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Being very impertinent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: So, so—I must be all submission, I find.

DIV3.STAGE: [He moves to a corner of the room, and sits down, affecting a silent dejection.]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: (After a pause.) I desire you will leave me instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Certainly—I will [rising] but condescend to tell me wherefore—for if my affectionate ardour—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: "If my affectionate ardour!"—What ro∣mantic language!—You treat me as if I were a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: But I know you are very far from one.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Yes—nothing like a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: This sneer is insufferable.—I tell you what, Dorimant, I wish to hate you—for indeed you have so many imperfections—

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Oh, innumerable!—You are vain of your person—ashamed of your birth—submissive to your enemies—insincere to your friends—with a thousand worse faults; and yet, with them all—I can't help liking you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: As you call my sincerity in question, I will give you a proof of it immediately—You are haughty, envious, peevish, conceited, capricious, im∣prudent—with a thousand faults, and yet with them all—"I can't help liking you."

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No man shall marry me who does not think me perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: That resolution will not exclude me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No?—

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: No—for I think you a perfect woman

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: But you shall believe I have not one fault. Go, sir, leave me—yonder comes my sister, and I am tired of your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I am all obedience, to shew you how you must hereafter behave to me.
SP.STAGE: [Exit on one side— Lady Classick enters on the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: How dare he to see one fault in me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Dear sister, would you have poor Dorimant blind?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Why not, as well as sir John, when he married?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You think he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: But don't mistake me—I believe his eyes are open now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Not to the charms of every one who may wish to captivate h

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Is there any such person?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I have heard so.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Before his marriage there might be, be∣cause the ladies all imagined he would be a difficult conquest—But after being so easily caught, I don't think there is a woman in the world would be at the trouble of conquering him a second time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: It would be a trouble, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Without any reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: True—for all the honour he can confer, he has bestowed on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And bestowed so much—he has given up all his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Emily, I have too long borne with these unkind insinuations—Reflections cast upon myself I can forgive, but when you make these attacks upon sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: The truth is so glaring, you can't bear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear sister, we will not remain here to∣gether, thus eternally to dispute—either you or I will fix upon some other abode.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Oh! sir John, I am going away—you are just come in time to take your leave—I am desired to quit your house instantly—your wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Don't let me hear that name.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Why this delicacy—when my anxiety to tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If you have the affection of a husband—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I won't hear that name.—What is all this?—What do you both want to tell me?—What nonsense?—You have had a quarrel, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Nonsense!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Nonsense—I should not have thought of that!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You must know, my dear—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I won't be called my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Why then, sir John—My sister has behav∣ed—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No—my sister has behaved—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! you have both behaved, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Your indifference is unkind.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Every thing is indifferent to him, but what is written in a book.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Look there now—they are going to quarrel with me.—But come, compose yourselves—and tell me, Matilda, how this affair between your sister and you began.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Ask her.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No—tell it yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: [After considering.] I don't remember how it began.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [After considering.] Nor I either.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
The fact is, you have both been quarrel∣ing,
and neither of you can tell why.—But pray do not let me interrupt you—for nothing is so entertaining to me as to hear ladies disagree.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Then you shall not be entertained at our expence, for we will instantly forgive each other.— Sister, I pardon you sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And I am sure I pardon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And do shake hands, to be revenged on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: And with mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And to shew how angry I am, I'll kiss you both.

DIV3.STAGE: MR. TRADEWELL CLASSICK enters during the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Well employed, upon my word, nephew.
SP.STAGE: Sir John starts—and the ladies exeunt in confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Aside.] My uncle—Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: I am sorry I should intrude upon your private studies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: A philosopher, I find, is but a human creature after all!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Dear sir—these ladies you saw here— are—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Aside.] I don't know what to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Finish your sentence—Speak— What are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: They are [hesitating]—sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Well—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Hesitating.] From the country—and as they are going into the country again—I was taking my leave of them—as you saw.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: But what brought them here?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A mere accident.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P:
I don't like accidents, when women are in the ease—They are the cause of many unlucky
accidents—and I would have nothing impede the busi∣ness upon which I came to speak to you.—I have pro∣cured you a wife—I know you have pretended an aver∣sion to matrimony—but that was merely to some of its forms, and in this case something more substantial is to be attended to; the lady I have chosen is young, hand∣some, and, above all, very rich; and some family rea∣sons will make it necessary the marriage should take place within a few days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Destruction [Aside]—But who is the la∣dy, sir?—Perhaps—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: There is no perhaps—for she is my daughter-in-law—my wife's only child—and with a fortune—You don't seem pleased—Let me tell you, the lady must not be despised.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Despised, sir!—No, no—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: No buts, sir—You have written against matrimony to make your book sell—So far you did right—I would write against it myself if I could get any thing by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: My pockets are filled with parch∣ments—follow me into your library, there we will look them over, and take care there's no cheating, unless it should be on our side—follow me, for I am growing old, and not so expert at those things as I used to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Sir, lord Lovemore called to tell you he will dine with you to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: More good news; [Aside.] send to him, and let him know—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: We need not send to him, sir, he is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Here!—Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: With my mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: More good news.— [Aside.] Let him know my uncle is unexpectedly arrived—I cannot come to him just now—but in about half an hour—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Oh! you need make no apology, sir—he won't think the time long.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: No—as he is with my mistress, he won't mind waiting—he'll not be impatient—you need not hurry yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: If that's the case, I shall hurry myself.

DIV3.STAGE: [Exit, in haste, on the opposite side to where he was going.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Another apartment at SIR JOHN's—LORD LOVERULE, SIR JOHN and LADY discovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: My dear sir John, I excuse you most wil∣lingly, for I know how much depends upon your pleas∣ing the old contractor, and how difficult it is to please him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And in one thing he has just proposed, I fear it will prove impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: He has chosen me a wife, and wants me to marry immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You marry—you—ha, ha, ha, ha—does he know your resolution?—does he know that you would not marry the finest woman in the world?— [Sir John shews evident signs of uneasiness.]—to marry would make you the laughing-stock of the whole town—You, that have laughed at every married man!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Uneasy.] They don't make me laugh so much as they did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: No—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No—but I think I pity them more than I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And does your old uncle imagine he can pre∣vail upon you to quit a bachelor's life?—impossible— and yet, would you believe it, there are some people in this town credulous enough to report you are married —but I take care to vindicate your character,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Thank you—I am very much obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P:
No, sir John, I never will stand silently by, and hear your firmness of temper called in question— the lady [bowing to lady C.] I tell them, may have charms to captivate the coldest heart, yet between her and sir John, I am positive no other than a sincere
friendship subsists; for he himself has told me so a hun∣dred times.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I suppose I have—to be sure—you are quite right.
SP.STAGE: [He makes signs to lady C. who appears anxious to speak, to be silent.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And now, my dear sir John, as I know you to be not only her friend, but mine, permit me to re∣peat, in your presence, what in private I have a thou∣sand times uttered.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And as a friend to us both, exert your friend∣ship for both our happiness—for if my esteem, my love, my adoration of you, beautiful Matilda— [seizing her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Sir John—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Nay, do not frown upon the man who doats upon you to distraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Aside.] I make a very respectable fi∣gure here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But receive my vows—receive my everlasting love:

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Rise, my lord, or I instantly quit the place. — [Aside to sir John.] Can you see this unmoved?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Be quiet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: [Rising.] Then let this, and this, seal my pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Running to him.] 'Sdeath, how can you be so foolish—you would not marry, sure—don't persist, for if you do you will lose my friendship—Let go her hand, there is witchcraft in the touch.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then why do you touch it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I can, with the coldness of a philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And would I could—would I were in your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And would I were in your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
I mean—I mean, my lord, that I per∣ceive your passion is a very serious one; and yet it is my advice you do not give way to it—do not, for my
sake—you know my friendship for you, and how sorry I should be to see you bound by those ties from which only death can release.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Oh! your old fashioned opinion of matrimony I begin to despise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But I have lately conceived a worse opi∣nion of it than ever—besides, while she persists in re∣jecting your passion, you ought to submit; unless, in any of your former interviews, she has encouraged your hopes—and in that case—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I appeal to his lordship's own honour—If I have, sir, explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, come, my lord, explain—and I will be judge between you.—What hopes has she ever given you?—I don't mean merely in promise, but in manners, looks, sighs, tears, sadness, joy, or sorrow?—Come, be particular, or you take from me the power of deci∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why then, to be particular—the first time I disclosed my passion to her, she burst into a fit of laugh∣ter—the second time, she insisted on my leaving the room.—But the third time she received me with every mark of kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Very well!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: My dear lord, said she—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Very well!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: My dearest creature, cry'd I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Very well!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have, said she, a sister, far more beautiful and amiable than myself, to whom I request you will transfer your affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Very well! [pleased]—and why do you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What! transfer my affection!—never—no— though she try'd to make me jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Did she—of whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That I can't tell—but the ungrateful woman swore her heart was engaged, and that nothing could eradicate the fixed and tender affection rooted there for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And can you persist after this, my lord? —for my sake don't.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: A passion like mine, makes the heart rebel∣lious—it will love on—it will hope, in spite of the rules cold reason dictates.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I know my uncle is impatient for my re∣turn, and therefore I cannot remain any longer here— but I am sorry to leave you—very sorry to leave you in this situation, indeed, my lord—Now promise to get the better of your pason—it will make me much hap∣pier if you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I can promise nothing—why don't you go to your uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am going—I must go, or he'll never pardon it— [aside.]—Adieu, my lord, for the present, and think on my advice— [Aside, going reluctantly, and turning back to observe.] This is the first trial of phi∣losophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: By heaven, I begin to suspect what report has told me; that he is the favour'd lover—but surely it cannot be—I must be more worthy your partiality than he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: You have your taste, my lord, and I have mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But reflect upon my birth, my title, my for∣tune.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh! when a heart gives itself away, depend upon it, it never reflects upon the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: And is it possible you can yield your charms to a cold philosopher?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: If he is warm to me, his coldness upon all other occasions does me the greater honour—farewel, and believe, that to whom so ever I have given my heart, it is gone past recal.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
What, still sighing, my lord?—still repeat∣ing vows of everlasting love to one who will not listen,
but while she holds your heart a captive, inhumanly exposes you to the derision of a rival.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Tell me who that rival is, and my obligations to you will be unbounded.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: If I do tell you, will you promise to fight him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That is an engagement—I don't like to enter into—and why should you request it?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Because both he and you have offended me, by prefering my sister, and I should like to see you engaged in a duel, through pure revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Now I suspect who my rival is—'tis Dori∣mant—your jealousy convinces me of it, for I know you love him, and I once thought the affection mutual.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Be not too confident you have found out your rival—you may be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But I am sure I am not—and he is beneath my notice—I shall yet win her from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That is impossible—because whoever Matilda loves—he is her husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: What! [Starting.] Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Yes, married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Distraction!—my hopes for ever gone—my pride, my vanity piqued.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Notwithstanding your endeavour to conceal it, I see vexation painted on your countenance—indeed, my lord, I pity you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Pity me—that's worse than the loss of the woman [Aside.]—By heaven, if you think I am chagrined, or even disappointed, you wrong me—I never loved seriously—do you suppose I meant to marry?—ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Come, be composed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, madam, I am composed— [raising his voice.] 'Tis you, and you only, that make me otherwise —for here I vow, if I feel a momentary pang, the least sense of sorrow, it is solely in compassion to the poor husband—him I pity, even while I despise and laugh at him.—Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And these are your real sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: My real sentiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I wish sir John knew them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Because, from the friendship sir John has for you, and suspecting your love for the lady, as soon as he is told of this marriage, he will dread the effect it may have on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Then at once to put him out of doubt, I will go and tell him my sentiments—and we will both laugh at the husband—ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Do—that is right—now that is just right—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But have I your permission to tell the secret to sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Yes, you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Thank you—thank you. I am much obliged to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: But you must not say you heard it from me— nor hint you know who her husband is—as indeed you don't; for that is a secret I gave my word not to reveal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I understand you—you did not absolutely say, but only hinted it was Dorimant—no matter who it is —be it who it will, we will make sport of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That's right.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Where is sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: With his uncle at present—come, take a few turns in the garden, and when I find you are in a per∣fect humour to laugh with him. I'll conceive to send him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I am very much obliged to you—you are very ind.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ay, you can't think how I love to do a good-natured action.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II. Another apartment at SIR JOHN's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter SIR JOHN and MR. TRADEWELL, following a SERVANT.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P:
My poor father came so unexpectedly,
and so many miles to see me?—Conduct him instantly hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: What—my unfortunate brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Dear uncle, do not behave unkindly to my father, and destroy the pleasure he will take in see∣ing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: And what it to you if I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What is it to —strange question!— reect what he is to me, and wonder how you can ask it.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter MR. CLASSICK, and embraces his son.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: My dear son, what pleasure do I feel in seeing and embracing you again—You, the sole sup∣port of my declining years—the sole prop of my de∣clining spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: [Going up to him.] And what brings you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Sure I may be permitted to visit my own son, without being called to an account.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Your visit, notwithstanding, might be dispensed with— [to sir John]—he does not come so many miles for the pleasure of seeing you—he has some new wants to be supplied, I warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Whatever be the motive, his coming gives me pleasure. [Aside to Tradewell]—Your behaviour pierces me to the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: To meet my son and my brother both together, is a happiness unexpected—and since it has thus happened, I will enjoy the pleasure the meeting gives me, without suffering the seeming unkindness of any one to diminish it.—Heaven bless you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Ay, be liberal of your blessings, for you have nothing else to bestow—no other portion to give your son.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And I value them much more than all your inheritance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P:
These are the precepts of philoso∣phy. But by our ordinary rules, a father takes care, and provide for his children. Between him and you
the order of nature has been reversed, for these ten years past.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: And I glory more to live at his ex∣pence, than were he to live at mine—the benefits I re∣ceive from him come to me like blessings; and their value is doubled by the pleasure I see him take in bestowing them.—But these are sensations which your heart is unacquainted with.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: What has made you thus poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Honour and honesty.—What has made you thus rich?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: [Hesitating.] You know I have been for many years a contractor—had I depended on my honour and honesty, I might have been as poor as you—and with all your contempt of the means of acquiring riches, you have no objection to partake of them—you have submitted to my becoming a father to your son, from his infancy; and now, while you, with all your boasted affection, cannot give him a shilling, I am going to marry him to a large fortune, and to settle another upon himself. Does this wound your delicacy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: No—it almost makes me weep in gra∣titude—but to whom are you going to marry him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: She's the daughter of my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: I rejoice at such an alliance.—Come, brother, let these approaching nuptials unite us all in love and friendship; forget our frivolous differences, for in my heart I am grateful and affectionate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Some obstacles may prevent the marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Oh no—it has no doubt been planned with too much care.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Brother, it is one of the best con∣tracts I ever made.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But allow me time, sir, to gain the lady's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: A lady's heart may be gained in a day—sometimes in an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Not such a heart as I would possess.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Well—I'll give you eight days—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: That is too short a time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Not too short to win eight hundred women—I wish I had a contract for as many as I myself could win in that time—and by sending them to the ladies I have no doubt but I might encrease my fortune half a million.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: How much soever I may dread your re∣sentment, sir, I must declare I cannot marry at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Reflect, my son.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I do reflect, but 'tis too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: If ye belong to me—but no—it is to him you belong—and him you are like—had you been mine, then you might have been like me, comply∣ing, obedient, amiable, and gentle—but till you prove yourself so, I have done with you—nor will I give six∣pence to a man, who does not look up to me as a pattern and model for all his action▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Follow ▪ my son, and promise to obey with chearfulness—he has virtues you should re∣spect—you have obligations which are binding—and this proposed marriage beyond any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: What is the matter?—Where is your usual joy on seeing me?—perhaps my coming has dis∣pleased you—if so, seek no excuses but let me go away, and come another time, when yu pect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Expect you—Must I exct your coming, to form my features in a smile to meet you?—No— your presence always gives me joy, no preparation could put on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: I believe you.—But why thus melan∣choly?—This intented marriage is perhaps the cause of your uneasiness.—Come, acknowledge your affections are placed upon some other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: They are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Perhaps they are bound by some en∣gagement?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: I am sorry for it—but go on—I commend you—Who is the object of your love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My wife.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Your wife!—Are you then married?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes—I consulted affection, and not am∣bition, and have therefore concealed my marriage; lest the world, as well as you, should blame me for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Is your wife prudent?—Is she such as you wished to find her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: She is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Then you have made an excellent match.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: This kindness consoles, and makes me less unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Here in this house, accompanied by her sister, and another lady, who passes for her relation, and the mistress of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: We m think of some expedient to divert your uncle's attention for the present, and during the delay we may contrive some means to declare your marriage with safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But the idea of the event being divulged, after having thus long concealed it, makes me all con∣fusion—sooner or later I shall get the better of this strange humour—but at present I cannot suppress the shame I feel, lest the world should know I am married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Do not be ashamed of a good woman —you philosophers are ever searching after novelty, and what could you show the world more worthy their attention than a good wife?—In all your researches, my son, nothing could so well establish yours, and your children's fame. What are plants and minerals?—Im∣prove human nature, that is the first great work of a philosopher.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. An apartment at SIR JOHN's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Where shall I hide me, from my uncle's solicitations?—Where hide me from my own reflections? —Oh! that I could but shake off this idle fear of the world, and own I am married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, [laughing] ha, ha, ha, ha, ha—Oh! I shall die—I shall never recover it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Alarmed.] What's the matter?—What are you laughing at?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: At the sight of you.—Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [More alarmed still.] At the sight of me?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I have such a secret to tell you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Earnestly.] What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: It concerns Matilda.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Starting.] Indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And does it concern any body else?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: It does—But you'll keep it a secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Depend upon me—What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: [Whispering.] Matilda is married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Starting.] You don't say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: She is, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You don't say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I do.—She is married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But do you know to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: No—But I guess.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I guess it is to Dorimant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Aside] Thank heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: [Overhearing him.] Why do you thank heaven?—Are you glad she is married?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No, my lord, very sorry, I assure you!— I would give a good deal she was not—And you, I suppose, are deeply concerned too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha—Do you imagine I meant to marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: [Angrily.] You said so before me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But that was after she had declared her heart engaged, and I knew she would not accept my offer.— I marry!—I marry!—I become a husband!—I be made the fool of a woman!—No, no, no.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: S'death!— [In great agitation]—And yet wiser men than you have married.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But none so wise as you; and it is my ambi∣tion to be in every thing as wise as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Who has informed you of this secret?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: That I must not say—nor shall I let Matilda know I am acquainted with it; but redouble my assidu∣ities, still urging her to what I know she cannot accept: and thus, in time, soften that heart which, in time, will harden to all the insipid attentions of a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But have you no respect for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha—Respect for a husband!—Had you ever any?—Whoever he is, don't you despise him? —But why don't you laugh?—You won't laugh?— You used to laugh on these occasions.—What a solemn countenance!—S'death—I beg pardon, sir John—In∣deed I do.—But a thought this moment strikes me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Nay, perhaps I wrong you—and yet the per∣son who told me this secret had some doubts who the husband was—and upon my soul (forgive me if I am mistaken) by your strange, awkward manner, and me∣lancholy countenance, something tells me—perhaps you are he?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am he, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: "No, you don't say so!"—"You don't say "so?"—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Yes—I see it is true—that is the very gait of a married man—How strange, I could not perceive it before.—But, my dear sir John, pray forgive my hav∣ing laughed—Upon my honour, had I known, had I conceived you had been the husband, I would not have laughed before your face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Refrain from it now then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I will—And as I know no better method, than by quitting your presence—I take my leave.— [Go∣ing—returns.]—But before I go, can I mediate between you and your uncle, or you and your father?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: To the world, however, you may depend upon it, I will paint the circumstance in the most favour∣able light—I will say, your falling in love was but a weakness attendant on human nature—your shame of owning it; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My lord, my lord, you'll make me for∣get myself.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Sir John, sir John, you have forgot yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Leave this room, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I will— [goes, and returns.]—and I'll send your wife to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: How painful is my situation!—Shall then the object that was to have bestowed happiness on me, be the sole cause of all my misery?—
My resolution is fixed; nor do you, Dorimant, at∣tempt to shake it.—I leave London this day, never to see that, or lady Classick more.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Sure you have lost your senses!—What will the world say of you then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: When I am away, that will be indifferent.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: But your wife, Matilda—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: She has been the cause of all—And hav∣ing had the pleasure of telling the secret she has a husband, she may now have the pleasure of telling the secret she has none.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: You cannot be in earnest?—She will not submit to a separation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: She must.—Who's there?
Desire her—her ladyship, to come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: [Surprised.] Who, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Lady Classick—my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Pray, sir, which of the ladies is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Do you not know?

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Yes, sir—But I thought I was not to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Even this fellow is laughing at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: No, upon my word, sir—Ha, ha, ha!— No, indeed, sir—Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: See what I am come to!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Would I were married to Emily, as you are to Matilda!—And I have hopes my wish will be very soon accomplished: for I have just received intel∣ligence I may assume my real name, and put an end to every objection she has conceived to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! here comes my wife—I am agitated —I dread to tell her what I know she will be concerned to hear.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Why then have you determined so rashly?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Can I stay, and expose myself to the re∣proaches of my uncle?—To the jests of the town?—But will you, Dorimant, endeavour to find my father, and tell him my determinations—aud tell him also—

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: To persuade you to alter them—That I shall certainly tell him.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LADY CLASSICK, EMILY, and LUCY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I am glad you have brought company with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: My dear sir John, is it your uncle who is the cause of this seeming uneasiness?—Tell me if it is—and put an end to my anxiety.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Your ladyship's anxiety may now entirely cease—The wish of your heart is fulfilled—Our mar∣riage is publicly known—I am congratulated every moment by one friend or other—and it is to you, ladies, I am under the obligation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: I had been insincere, could I have denied the pride it gave me to be supposed your wife—but if ever that pride tempted me to drop a hint—except to the marquis—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And I call heaven to witness, I never breathed a syllable of it, except to half a dozen of my most inti∣mate friends, and people whom I knew would be as particular not to mention it, as I myself would be.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I wish I may not stay another hour in my lady's service, if I ever told it to a single soul except mrs. Fringe, the milliner, and mr. Puff, the hair∣dresser; and I am sure they never mentioned it again, for they promised me they would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: No more of this—I have done with my accusations—I have done with you all, too.—I leave London this night, and it will be some time before you hear from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh heaven! I cannot survive this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Are you not known to be my wife?— What more would you require?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Require, my husband?—not to be thus aban∣doned—left unprotected.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I shall leave you in the care of my father; and he will protect you from the insults of my uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: But who is to protect me from the insults of the world?—Protect me from that fixed affection rooted in my heart for you?—And from the remembrance of your unkindness?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Could you live with me in the retreat that I shall fly to?—Could you quit the pleasures of the world?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: To me, the pleasures of the world can only be where you are▪

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I am out of all patience—Oh! that you were but my husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: As I went out, sir John, I met your uncle and your father, both returning—and your uncle communicated to me a project he means immediately to put into execution.—He has been informed of your mar∣riage, that it took place abroad, and without all the due forms to render it legal—He therefore means to annul it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Oh heavens!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Annul my marriage?—Let him—then openly, and in the face of day, I'll marry her again.— [Going, and taking her hand.]—Annul my marriage?— Make void the happiest action of my life?—An act which gave to my gloomy mind a friend, a soothing partner to reform it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Is this my husband?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes—but, in the fear of losing you, a lover still.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Now, would you were my husband in good earnest!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What ceremonies were wanting.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Indeed, sir, I don't think the parson or you forgot one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And pray what said my father to my un∣cle's proposal?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: At first he pleaded for your union to be acknowledged; but upon your uncle declaring, that on those terms he would disinherit you, he appeared to submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I will go to them immediately, and my uncle shall find—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Wait till his resentment may, in some mea∣sure, be abated!—Oh! for me to be the cause of your ruin!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Retire, my love, and do not appear till I send for you—But remain in full confidence, that if I give way to my passion, it is for your sake—or if I suppress it, it is still for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: This situation, in spite of myself, makes me compassionate them both—and in spite of myself, it makes me long to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I should hope I caused that desire more than any thing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: You?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Yes—and when you are my wife—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I your wife?—I should be glad to see it!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I know you would—and so should I.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I marry a man without family or fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Sir John is my witness—I have both— enquire of him, and be convinced.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Dear lady, I this moment parted from mr. Tradewell Classick, and he assures me he is going to set aside your sister's marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Very true, my lord—and this is the time for you—a woman disconsolate and forsaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: But she shan't be forsaken; in spite of all I may have said, I have a great mind to go and offer my∣self to her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And if you do, my lord, I'll answer for the event.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You advise me, then.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I do—for it will give me great pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: [Bowing.] You are very good—you are, upon all occasions, my good friend—You first discovered to me the marriage, though you could not tell me with whom—and then, unfortunately, you sent me to laugh at the very man himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: How then can you offer yourself on the present occasion? for he, no doubt, has told her what you said.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No matter, his lordship can unsay it—he can go and protest to sir John, what he said was the mere effect of resentment; for that while he laughed, he was ready to cry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: If I thought such an acknowledgment would have any effect—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Depend upon it, it will have great effect.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Where is sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I believe, at present, with my sister—go, go, make atonement.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: You will answer for my reception?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Thank you—thank you—and I think I can answer for it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! Sir John deserves this recom∣pence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: But I doubt it is less in recompence to sir John, than in spleen to his lordship.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter MR. CLASSICK and MR. T. CLASSICK.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Oh the great scholar, that could not learn to live single a few years—the great philosopher, who scorns to understand the value of money: nor from me shall he ever know the comforts of it; for I disinhe∣rit him, but upon one condition—unless he consents to declare his marriage invalid.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [Coming forward.] Abandon a wife whom he has sworn to love and protect!—and who is to forgive you for making such a proposal?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Oh! your humble servant, madam —What, you are the pretended wife, I suppose?—you are the lady who has ensnared him?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ensnare—ensnare a man with his head forti∣fied with Latin and Greek, and his heart made hard with philosophy.—You might as well suppose a poor honest tradesman could ensnare a rich, hardened con∣tractor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Here's a vixen—reflecting on the means by which I have acquired my riches—But let me tell you, madam, my nephew's marriage is an illegal one, and I will take care to make you both ashamed of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: In that case, we cannot retaliate, for I sup∣pose there is not any thing you would be ashamed of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Is this the gentle spirit you de∣scribed to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Such was the character I received— but give me leave to say, madam, you have departed from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: Oh what a bargain the great man has made.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Not so good a bargain as some of yours have been.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: But while he acknowledges this woman, his crime shall be his punishment—I will no longer be his banker. Let him apply to his studies—a philosopher can extract gold from base metal.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And a contractor can extract it, from every thing that comes in his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: Let us be gone, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Be patient, gentlemen, for I assure you this lady is not the wife of sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: I know she is not—and I'll have it proved.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [To Dorimant.] And do you pretend to say sir John is not lawfully married?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: No—I did not say that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: How, sir, do you contradict your∣self? Pray were you the witness to a legal marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: ere, you see she has brought him over [To Classick.]—this man I have often seen at sir John's, is, I dare say, some poor relation, or some at∣torney.—I'll put him to the proof— [To Dorimant, aside.]—Hark you, sir, do you mean to be a witness on the trial, and swear she is the lawful wife of my ne∣phew?—Here, take this purse— [gives it to him.]—and tell me now, what will you swear?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: What do you wish me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: That, that lady is not my nephew's lawful wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: I will swear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: And keep your countenance?

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: And keep my countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: You are cleverer than I thought you—a perfect man of business.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: But I'll swear it without your purse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: He is no attorney after all.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LORD LOVEMORE, and goes to EMILY.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Do you know I have made myself ridiculous!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Is that possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: They both laughed at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And why did you not laugh again?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: I did—but that did not prevent their laughing on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: [Going to him.] I can tell you what, sir—notwithstanding the trick you have played me, I am going to do you a kind turn for it.—I am go∣ing to take your wife from you; and you should be obliged to me, for taking away such a termagant—She has treated me—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: It is true—She has treated your uncle in a manner unworthy the woman you should love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My wife?—It cannot be!—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LADY CLASSICK, SIR JOHN meets her, and takes her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Here is my father and my uncle, who both accuse you of treating them with disrespect—Is it possible my Matilda can deserve such a charge?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: In aspiring to be yours, I own my offence— but in no one circumstance else, has even my heart, much less my lips, presumed to offend—nor had I ever, till this moment, the confusion to appear before either of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
But I, knowing the cruel design of these
gentlemen, took the liberty to represent my sister, and behaved on the occasion as she ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: [To mr. Classick.] In what do I merit the severity I am threatened with?—In having complied with the desires of a beloved son, can I be the object of his father's resentment?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: In you, madam, I approve my son's choice, nor would have it changed, had he the power to make you happy. But without the concurrence of his uncle, you must live in poverty, and his determina∣tion is fixed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: [To mr. Tradewell.] To you, sir, I have nothing to offer in my behalf, except my tears, my heart-wounding sorrows.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: I refuse those offers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady.
SP.P: Accept, then, my submission. To have gain∣ed your approbation I would have knelt and supplicated; but as that must not be—suffer me to kneel and plead for a nephew, to whom you have ever been indulgent— Let me not be the cause of his misfortunes—Pardon him —take him to your heart again—and, hard as the task is, I consent never to see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: What's the matter, brother?—You hesitate.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Dear uncle, if you feel the least ray of pity—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: For the first time in my life, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Then cherish it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Tradewell.
SP.P: [After a pause, as struggling with his inclination.] I will—and give my consent that you shall cherish your wife.— [Gives her to him.]—And yet I cannot but be sorry she was not like her [pointing to Emily] that when she knelt, I might have thrown her from me—But as it is—as it is— [struggling]—I can't help forgiving her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! my Matilda! who can doubt your power?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Since she has proved it there— [pointing to Tradewell.]—What's the matter, my lord?—You look
concern'd?—Can't you, as usual, laugh at your disap∣pointment?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha— [affecting to laugh—he stops short.]—No—I can't laugh so well as I did—And I be∣lieve it would be much easier for me to shed a few tears.

SP.SPEAKER: Dorimant.
SP.P: Nay, my lord, for once, if possible, for∣get your disappointment, and partake the joy of your friends.—My happiness is superlative, for Emily has just consented to be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have been an impostor—for while I could equivocate with my friend, and blush at being the husband of such a wife as this, I usurped, like many others, the title of philosopher, without having a claim to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Classick.
SP.P: And believe me, my son, while you fill the station as you ought to do, no title is more ho∣nourable than that of A MARRIED MAN.
